Author Full Names: Saurabh, Mathur; Singh, Rathore Shiv; Gaurav, Chauhan; Anugya, Shukla; Chandra, Mathur Suresh
Article Title: Geoheritage Significance of Siwana Ring Complex, Western Rajasthan, India: Implication for a Potential Geopark Site
Author Keywords: Siwana ring structure; Malani igneous suite; Geodiversity; Geosites; Geoheritage; Geopark; Geotourism
Keywords Plus: IMPACT STRUCTURE; SHATTER CONES; BARMER DISTRICT; STISHOVITE; COESITE; QUARTZ; ROCKS; VREDEFORT; BRECCIA
Abstract: The Siwana Ring Complex (SRC), located in western Rajasthan, India, is a distinctive elliptical to circular geological structure featuring three annular rings. SRC is notable for its Neo-Proterozoic Malani Igneous Suite (MIS) of bimodal igneous rocks. The SRC's unique geological and mineralogical characteristics, including the presence of reported high-pressure minerals such as stishovite and coesite, underline its global scientific importance, particularly regarding the Pan-African orogeny. The enrichment of alkali, uranium, thorium, and silver mineralization, along with rare earth elements (REE) in the Igneous Type Georesources (ITG) of the SRC, underscores its economic importance. Consequently, the ITG of the SRC displays remarkable global geodiversity, constituting important stratotype sections in India. Notable geosites within the SRC, such as Rakhi, Phulan, and Dantala, embody significant geoheritage elements important for education and tourism but face threats from natural erosion and human activities. To safeguard these sites and promote sustainable development, the establishment of a Geopark is proposed to conserve the significant geoheritage of SRC while fostering local economic benefits through geotourism.

Authors: Dharaiya, A; Gaikwad, S; Sangode, S; Singh, R; Thakkar, M
Author Full Names: Dharaiya, Aditya; Gaikwad, Satyajit; Sangode, Satish; Singh, Ramdayal; Thakkar, Mahesh
Article Title: A Rigorous Comparative Geological Evaluation of a Potential Martian Terrestrial Analog Site from Kachchh Sedimentary Basin of NW India: A Geoheritage Significance
Source Title: JOURNAL OF THE INDIAN SOCIETY OF REMOTE SENSING
Author Keywords: Jarosite; Smectites; Sedimentology; Paleo-environment; Mineral mapping
Keywords Plus: WESTERN INDIA; MINERALS; IDENTIFICATION; CRISM; KUTCH; MARS
Abstract: The exploration of Mars and its geologic history has captivated scientists and the public alike. Terrestrial analogues Earth locations with geological features resembling Martian terrains are critical for bridging Earth-based research with planetary exploration. The Kachchh basin in northwestern India, particularly the Matanomadh Formation, is a noteworthy analogue site. This late Paleocene formation exhibits sedimentary structures like cross-stratified sandstone, clay pockets, and weathered lateritic profiles, resembling Martian landscapes such as Mawrth Vallis and Meridiani Planum. Key minerals, including jarosite and hydrous sulfates, identified through XRD and other geochemical techniques such as SEM-EDS, further enhance its relevance due to their association with ancient aqueous activity on Mars. Fieldwork and remote sensing reveal depositional features indicative of dynamic fluvial processes, akin to ancient Martian riverbeds. Jarosite's presence suggests acidic, oxidizing conditions, mirroring Mars' Noachian to Hesperian transition. The study also highlights connections to Earth's Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum, offering insights into both planetary and terrestrial climate history. Recognizing the Matanomadh Formation as a Geoheritage site would ensure its preservation, promote scientific research, and foster sustainable geotourism. Its study not only advances Mars exploration but also deepens our understanding of Earth's geologic past, emphasizing the interconnectedness of planetary processes.

Article Title: Geotourism Potential of the Nakora Ring Complex, Western Rajasthan, India
Author Keywords: Nakora ring complex; Jain temple; Geotourism; Temple architecture
Keywords Plus: MALANI IGNEOUS SUITE; TECTONIC EVOLUTION; GEOCONSERVATION; GEOHERITAGE; TOURISM; MAGMATISM; AUSTRALIA; GEOPARKS; HISTORY; PART
Abstract: Neoproterozoic volcano-plutonic Nakora Ring Complex (NRC) is well known for the presence of its Nakora Parshvanath Jain Temple, which is surrounded by the Nakora hills. NRC mainly consists of volcanic, plutonic, and dyke phases. NRC rocks are outcropped in a semi-circular structure along which the luni river takes a U-turn from the west to the south direction. NRC site is highly respected and significant among Jain pilgrims, and thousands of pilgrims visit annually. At NRC, there are a total of eight hills in the form of a ring, with a volcanic vent, spectacular columnar structures and beautiful spheroidal features. The site contains intricate architecture in the temple and residential bhavans (hostels). NRC is a truly fascinating site that has been well studied geologically, but it has not been promoted as a geo-tourism destination, as it is situated in a desert region of western Rajasthan. This work presents, for the first time, the recognition of the NRC as a rich geological, cultural, and spiritual area that must be highlighted by regional and national authorities as a premier tourism site in western Rajasthan.

Authors: Prasad, GVR; Hughes, NC; Kumar, S
Author Full Names: Prasad, Guntupalli V. R.; Hughes, Nigel C.; Kumar, Sanjay
Article Title: The Indian Museum of Earth (TIME): A vision for the future
Source Title: JOURNAL OF THE PALAEONTOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF INDIA
Author Keywords: Palaeontology; fossil collections; national repository; TIME; India
Abstract: India possesses an extraordinary, yet largely untold, story of the co-evolution of Earth as a planet and life upon it. The crescendo of this story is the formation and later break-up of the supercontinent Gondwana, followed by the Indian subcontinent's solitary northward drift as an island landmass. This remarkable journey through diverse climates profoundly shaped its history as a unique travelling nursery of plant and animal life, a story etched in the fossils discovered across the subcontinent. India's Phanerozoic rocks hold globally significant palaeontological treasures, from dinosaur nesting sites and the earliest odd-toed mammals to ancient walking whales and some of the planet's oldest plant groups. Furthermore, the older Precambrian shield regions offer a glimpse into life before complex organisms evolved and are also vital repositories of mineral wealth. Astonishingly and sadly, despite this rich palaeontological and geological heritage, India lacks a central Natural History Museum to safeguard and showcase these treasures for public education and appreciation. To address this critical gap, the establishment of The Indian Museum of Earth (TIME) has been initiated through collaborative efforts supported by the office of the Principal Scientific Adviser to the Government of India. This account details the journey so far in creating this vital institution.

Author Full Names: Kapasya, Harish; Rathore, Monika Kanwar; Chauhan, Gaurav D.; Chauhan, Narendra Kumar
Article Title: Geoheritage and Geotourism Potential of Udaipur - Rajsamand - Desuri Belt of Rajasthan, India
Author Keywords: Geological heritage; Geotourism; Geosite; Aravalli-Delhi Fold Belt; Udaipur; Rajsamand; Desuri; Ophiolite suite; Precambrian tectonics; Geological conservation
Keywords Plus: ARCHEAN-PROTEROZOIC CONTACT; ARAVALLI CRATON; ROCKS; GEOMORPHOSITES; PALEOSOL; HISTORY; SITES
Abstract: Rajasthan, a state in northwestern India, is endowed with a rich geological, geomorphological, paleontological, faunal, floral, historical, and industrial diversity. This paper focuses on 10 geosites located in the Udaipur, Rajsamand, and Desuri regions, situated in the south-central part of Rajasthan. These geosites form part of the Aravalli and Delhi Fold Belts of the Aravalli Mountains, showcasing a diverse array of geological features, including Precambrian orogenic processes, collision tectonics, ophiolite suites, shallow shelf carbonate facies, and ancient global oxidation events, all remarkably preserved within this terrain. The proposed belt contains classic exposures of igneous and metamorphic rock assemblages, complex deformation patterns, and structural features that are prominently displayed along road cuts and nearby landscapes. These sites also hold cultural significance, with several ancient and revered temples, enhancing their value for geotourism. The belt has served as a natural laboratory for generations of geologists, providing fundamental field knowledge and inspiring numerous scientific studies. The proper conservation and scientific interpretation of these geosites will promote geotourism, support geological research, and foster public appreciation of Earth's geological heritage. Developing these sites with appropriate educational materials will also enhance field-based learning for students, researchers, and the general public. Conservation of these sites will benefit the national and international geological community, facilitating further research into the geological evolution of the Aravalli-Delhi Fold Belt. Therefore, the authors propose the systematic conservation of this belt for future geologists, researchers, students, and curious tourists, ensuring its preservation for generations to come.

Author Full Names: Joshi, M.; Thakur, V. C.; Sundriyal, Y. P.; Kotlia, B. S.; Bhakuni, S. S.; Singh, A. K.; Naik, S. P.; Kothyari, G. C.
Article Title: Archaeo-seismological Evidences of a Shifted Capital in Chamba Region of NW Himalaya
Author Keywords: Chamba; Bharmour; 1905 Kangra earthquake; Migration of civilization; Himalayan earthquakes historical record
Keywords Plus: 1905 KANGRA EARTHQUAKE; NORTHWEST HIMALAYA; CONSTRAINTS; RUPTURE; SECTOR; VALLEY; BASIN
Abstract: Bharmour, a small town and old capital of Chamba kingdom in NW Himalaya, is one of the oldest civilizations in the Himalayan region. Here civilization has existed at least seventh century. Shifting of capital by the King of Chamba from Bharmour to Chamba around the 10th Century, remains an unsolved puzzle. This poses a question that what were the factors that forced the King to shift his capital from Bharmour to Chamba? Did an earthquake force him, or was it related to other catastrophic events related to climate? We have studied the archaeological monuments of Bharmour, Chamba and Kangra regions for seismological study and core sediments of Khajjiar Lake for palaeoclimatic reconstruction for last 4400 years. The obtained results were corroborated with the published palaeo-seismological data of the region. The palaeo-climatic data of the past 1500 years indicate that there were stable climatic conditions in the region. The published palaeo-seismological study, over the surface rupture of 1905 earthquake, documented three historical earthquakes between (i) 2500-900 BC (ii) 890 BC-720 AD (iii) 750-1290AD. The third historical earthquake (750-1290 AD) corresponds to the shifting time of capital from Bharmour to Chamba (i.e tenth century). This suggests that a major earthquake may have been responsible for shifting of capital from Bharmour to Chamba. In addition to the rich cultural heritage, these monuments have a great potential to serve as geoheritage sites. These deformed monumental features can be used in educational exhibits, guided tours, and interpretive trails to educate people about the earthquake history of the region. It can also be used to stress the importance of being ready for disasters and building resilience in both locals and visitors.

Authors: Reddy, CS; Athira, K; Mudalkar, S
Author Full Names: Reddy, C. Sudhakar; Athira, K.; Mudalkar, Shalini
Article Title: Evolution of Global Biodiversity Monitoring: Innovations, Modern Approaches and Integration with Essential Variables
Source Title: JOURNAL OF THE INDIAN SOCIETY OF REMOTE SENSING
Author Keywords: Conservation; Remote sensing; Genetic; Ecosystem; Climate
Keywords Plus: DIVERSITY
Abstract: Biodiversity, climate, geodiversity and ocean systems are intricately linked and form the basis of the Earth's ecological balance. The integration of geospatial data, molecular techniques and advanced computational tools has diversified the utility of research for sustainable biodiversity management. Remote sensing together with environmental DNA techniques are revolutionizing biodiversity monitoring at high spatial and temporal scales. Species distribution models are now predicting biodiversity responses to climate change, while multi-omics approaches are advancing our understanding of genetic diversity. Recent advances in computational tools, geospatial technologies, artificial intelligence, machine learning and quantum computing offer the potential for even more sophisticated and effective methods of monitoring biodiversity on a global scale. Biodiversity research has evolved significantly over the years, transitioning from traditional species cataloging to highly sophisticated, computational approaches that integrate multiple disciplines. This transformation has been driven by advancements in technology, data science, and interdisciplinary research, enabling a more comprehensive assessment and monitoring of structural, compositional, and functional dimensions of biodiversity. By integrating data from terrestrial, marine, and atmospheric domains, we can better understand the feedback loops between biodiversity, climate, geodiversity, and ocean processes.

Article Title: Proposed geoheritage sites along the transects of the Lunavada and surrounding areas promoting sustainable tourism within NE Gujarat and SW Rajasthan, India
Author Keywords: Lunavada; Kadana; Eddy current markings; Sustainable tourism; Tourism led growth; Pro-environmental education; Geoheritage; Geotourism
Keywords Plus: REGION
Abstract: The Lunavada-Kadana Transect is an excellent area to display the geoheritage of the north-eastern region of Gujarat and south-western region of Rajasthan. It provides a diverse set of aspects to gawk at, stimulating the intrigue in one's mind as well as bringing a heightened sense of appreciation for Earth processes. This paper provides a concise summary of four viable and easily accessible traverses across the region. The sites were selected after several detailed field seasons based on numerous factors such as individuality, scenic views, tourist attraction, peculiarity, uniqueness, and potential for tourism education as well as scientific studies. Additionally, they have been assessed with a quantitative scheme to determine their suitability for becoming geosites. The present study has narrowed down thirteen sites, which have a wide range of geological aspects. This variation in the range can promote the area to become a field geological museum and an arena to hone one's field aptitude with a rich repository of literature published over the century. Such initiatives can also foster learning for sustainability by deepening our understanding of natural systems and encouraging responsible stewardship. Geosites are often overlooked and lost to the pages of obscurity buried within the pages of scientific literature; promoting them by granting the status of a Geoheritage site garners the attention of the masses as well as their appreciation for such features. Consequently, it becomes our duty to preserve such marvels as natural wealth for future generations through frameworks rooted in sustainable tourism and education for peace, ensuring that development is inclusive, mindful, and resilient.

Article Title: Geoheritage and Geotourism Potential of Andaman and Nicobar Islands: Classical Geosites for Conserving Marine System Outcrop for Education and Outreach
Author Keywords: Ophiolite suites; Turbidites sequences; Deep marine chalk; Trace fossils; Andaman and nicobar islands
Keywords Plus: PLANKTONIC FORAMINIFERAL BIOSTRATIGRAPHY; SAWAI BAY FORMATION; NEILL-ISLAND; FLYSCH-GROUP; ECOTOURISM DEVELOPMENT; TURBIDITE SUCCESSIONS; MIOCENE RADIOLARIAN; DIVERSITY PATTERNS; MUD VOLCANO; ARCHIPELAGO
Abstract: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands, located in the Bay of Bengal, are renowned for their pristine natural beauty, rich history, and diverse culture, making them a popular domestic tourist destination. The islands feature six distinct geotectonic units, including the Andaman Trench/Inner Slope, Outer High/Trench Slope Break, Fore Arc Basin, Volcanic Arc, Back Arc Basin, and Mergui Terrace. These regions comprise ophiolite, flysch deposits, and deep-marine sediments, which are easily accessible and offer valuable insights into deep-marine processes. The stratigraphic sequence of the islands encompasses metasedimentaries, an ophiolite complex, the Baratang Group, and the Archipelago Group. The Archipelago Group comprises seven formations, providing well-preserved deep-marine facies for detailed biostratigraphic analysis. These locations are for studying deep marine processes and sedimentation. The Port Blair Turbidites, characterized by excellent exposures, serve as classical examples for studying turbidite deposits. Petrological and sedimentological analyses have been conducted on these turbidites, providing valuable insights into their facies and characteristics. Additionally, the islands offer well-preserved chalk facies with diverse microfossils, presenting an excellent opportunity to study pelagic and hemipelagic sedimentation processes. Thus, it has become essential to preserve and protect Cretaceous sedimentary sequences for teaching and training purposes. We have identified nine major important geoheritage locations that should be preserved for the future. These sites are (1) Mauricedra Beach geosite (b) Panchwati geosites (c) Port Blair geosite (d) Baratang limestone (e) Mud volcanoes (f) Kalapathar geosite (g) Lacam Point (h) Natural rock arc (i) Bharatpur beach. These geosites are well-accessible and have been extensively studied for their geochemical and geochronological analysis, contributing to understanding the islands' geological evolution. The Andaman and Nicobar Islands possess significant geoheritage and geotourism potential, particularly in terms of their deep-marine outcrops. These sites provide valuable opportunities for geological studies, education, and outreach, enabling a better understanding of deep-marine processes and their significance in Earth's history.

Authors: Sarkar, A; Gayen, SK
Author Full Names: Sarkar, Alok; Gayen, Shasanka Kumar
Article Title: Mapping the Field: A Systematic Bibliographic Review of Geotourism Trends in the Twenty-First Century
Author Keywords: Geotourism; Bibliometric analysis; Bibliographical survey; Research trends; Scopus; VOSviewer
Keywords Plus: MANAGEMENT; GEOSITE; GEOCONSERVATION; SCOPUS; TOOL
Abstract: In the modern era, the tourism industry has experienced rapid growth, with geotourism emerging as a vital component. The popularity of geotourism has increased significantly in recent decades. The growing popularity and research on geotourism necessitate a thorough literature review. This study employs bibliometric analysis using Scopus databases to investigate geotourism articles in the twenty-first century thoroughly. This study uses VOSviewer and Bibliometrix software to analyze publication output, journals, geographical distribution, titles, and co-occurrence keywords to identify current research trends and future directions in this field The study highlights trending topics: geotourism, geoheritage, geoconservation, tourism development, and geosite. There's a 1139.02% surge in publications from 2002-2012 to 2013-2024, with Italy, Poland, Spain, and India as the leading nations in this field. The key conclusions highlight the significance of global cooperation, the need for innovative evaluation methods, and the incorporation of indigenous populations. Language barriers, inadequate comprehensive management and planning studies, and a Northern Hemisphere scientific concentration remain despite advances. This research highlights geotourism's interdisciplinary nature, quick growth, and critical role in sustainable development and conservation. To preserve geological variability for future generations, future research must match theoretical and practical applications and stimulate international cooperation.

Article Title: First Report of Fossil Wood from the Basgo Formation, Ladakh: Paleoclimatic, Taphonomic, and Geoheritage Significance
Source Title: JOURNAL OF THE GEOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF INDIA
Author Keywords: Fossil wood; Basgo; Ladakh; Palaeontological implications
Keywords Plus: SEDIMENTATION; HIMALAYA; MOLASSE
Abstract: The first report of fossil wood from the Basgo Formation near Basgo Fort, Ladakh, holds significant paleontological and paleoclimatic implications, providing insights into the taphonomic and tectonic conditions during its deposition. The Basgo Formation is situated between the Indus Group (comprising the Tar Turbidites, Nummulitic Limestone, and the Nurla and the lower Nimmu Formation) to the south and the Ladakh Batholith to the north. Lithologically, the formation is characterized by grey sandstone with pebbles and alternating red mudstone. The fossil locality, being adjacent to the Basgo Fort-a UNESCO World Heritage site-adds cultural and scientific value to the site. It is proposed to protect and preserve this site for further research and declare it a geoheritage site to boost Geotourism.

Authors: Kumar, P; Shekhar, S
Author Full Names: Kumar, Pramod; Shekhar, Shubhendu
Article Title: Conservation and Protection of the Assorted Geosites: Western Part of the Kutch Basin, India
Author Keywords: Entablature; Pillow lava; Fossil crab geosite; Taphonomy; Parasequence; Trace fossil
Keywords Plus: SEDIMENT DEFORMATION STRUCTURES; CARBON-ISOTOPE EXCURSION; SEQUENCE STRATIGRAPHY; OLIGOCENE; GEOHERITAGE; FORAMINIFERA; ARCHITECTURE; PLEISTOCENE; ENVIRONMENT; RECOGNITION
Abstract: Globally Cenozoic interval witnessed recurrent climatic change of warming and cooling episodes of various magnitudes. The geological archives of the western part of the Kutch Basin are bestowed with spectacular igneous structures formed during the Deccan Trap volcanism. Overlying, Cenozoic successions of the Kutch Basin also get affected by the global climatic perturbations, which get registered in their impressive stratigraphic successions. Sedimentation in the basin was primarily controlled by the rate of relative sea-level fluctuations vs. background siliciclastic supply. Combined effect of climatic perturbations and relative sea-level fluctuation along passive-margin setting resulted in the occurence of variety of fossils, lithology and sedimentary structures, available all over the Cenozoic outcrops. To conserve and protect endangered geological features, geoscientists around the world have recognized several geosites, which can serve as standard reference section for further research and sustainable development for generations. In this study, we identify some spectacular outcrops from the western parts of the Kutch Basin (Cenozoic outcrops and Deccan Trap exposures) and document their properties to be recognized as potential geosites. These sites preserve exclusive geological features and provide template to understand the geological processes, however, needs conservation and protection. We propose the following assorted geosites viz. (1) Entablature geosite, (2) Pillow lava geosite, (3) Taphonomy geosite, (4) Fossil crab geosite, (5) Trace fossil geosite and (6) Soft sediment deformation (SSD) geosite. These sites may serve as exclusive locations for students field excursion, field-training for diverse professionals, social outreach activities and future reference section; indeed helps to achieve the implementation of some of the geoheritage goals. Diverse and unique geological features can be easily approached by thoroughly connected rail network and metalled roads.

Authors: Goswami, S
Author Full Names: Goswami, Sukanta
Article Title: Geotourism in India: potential, challenges and sustainable practices
Author Keywords: Conservation status; geotourism sites; geological monuments; heritage; sustainable practices
Abstract: India, with its rich and diverse geological history, boasts a remarkable array of geological monuments and geotourism sites. These sites not only provide insight into the Earth's geological past, but also offer significant educational, recreational and economic benefits. The Geological Survey of India has identified and protected numerous sites of geological significance, fostering both conservation and geotourism. This study explores the Indian national geological monuments and geotourism sites, highlighting their significance, conservation status and potential for promoting geotourism. It also discusses the challenges and opportunities associated with the development and management of these sites.

Authors: Mandal, UK; Karmakar, M; Mondal, S; Tamang, L; Ghosh, D
Author Full Names: Mandal, Uttam Kumar; Karmakar, Manas; Mondal, Sajal; Tamang, Lakpa; Ghosh, Debasis
Article Title: An Appraisal of Evolution Stage and Degradation Risk of Geomorphosites Using TALC and DRA in Ajodhya Hill of the Eastern Chota Nagpur Plateau, India
Author Keywords: Geomorphosites; Tourism Area Life Cycle (TALC); Degradation Risk Assessment (DRA); Geo-conservation strategies; Chota Nagpur Plateau
Keywords Plus: GEODIVERSITY; MANAGEMENT; TOURISM; THREATS; CYCLE
Abstract: Tourism development often brings notable challenges to geo-conservation in natural areas. As tourist sites emerge at different evolutionary stages of tourism development, they may face various potential threats. This study examines the stages of tourism development and assesses the associated degradation risks using the Tourism Area Life Cycle (TALC) and Degradation Risk Assessment (DRA) frameworks on 14 geomorphosites in the Ajodhya hill area of the eastern Chota Nagpur plateau, famous for its diverse geological and geomorphological features and growing tourist attraction. Subsequently, the intricate relationship between the stages of tourism development and potential threats to geomorphosites are also addressed in this work. For the TALC analysis, 10 criteria and several indicators are considered to determine the current tourism development stage and DRA analysis using 20 parameters consisting of 4 indicators has been assessed. The findings reveals that, the most of the geomorphosites lies in the exploration stage except two geomorphosites (namely, Chunkadi spring and Jugni cave) with moderate to high risk of degradation. The extent of degradation in the region is largely influenced by mismanagement of sites, meteorological vulnerabilities and increasing public usage. Thus by addressing the most vulnerable risk factors, effective management strategies and conservation measures would assist towards sustainable geotourism development locally and also could be utilized for preservation of similar sites.

Authors: Misra, KS; Misra, A; Misra, N
Author Full Names: Misra, K. S.; Misra, Anshuman; Misra, Neela
Article Title: Thermal Baking, Induration and Physical Volcanic Features in Deccan Volcanic Units and Their Suitability for Excavation, Sculpturing as well as Restoration of Geoheritage Sites in Western India
Author Keywords: Thermal baking/induration; Basalt; Lava tube/channel; Excavation; Sculpturing and restoration; Geoheritage sites; Western India
Abstract: Deccan volcanic units cover vast region in west-central India and host some of the monumental geoheritage sites. These basalt units are not suitable either for excavation or sculpturing, because of inherent cooling cracks. Weathering of iron minerals also reduces their utilization for work of art. From the beginning of first century, ancient artisans have identified thermally baked zones in the vicinity of lava tubes, channels and effusive centres. Newly formed rocks within these zones are indurated, hardened and excellent for excavation, sculpturing and polishing. The degree of induration is also skilfully utilized, black basalt has acquired vibrant shades of red by amalgamating iron minerals. Depending on religious believes, Hindus excavated enormous Kailash temple from the top of the hill with intricate sculpturing of idols and statues, while Buddhists excavated large meditation halls (Vihars) with columns and arches. We identified hidden effusive centre in the vicinity of Ellora cave complex. Physical volcanic feature such as portal portion of lava tube is utilized for locating large Saptashrungi temple. Silica rich agglomerate basalt, with large fragments is used for coarse carving of tall Buddha statue, corresponding with the sixth-century Bamiyan caves in Afghanistan, while exceedingly fine-grained agglomerate is preferred for intricate carving of Shiva idol in Elephanta caves. Damage by invaders and erosion are usually repaired by cement and concrete, losing aesthetic sense. We recommend matching rocks for restoration and use of red ochre, blue and green (azurite and malachite) from copper and brown from bark extract for cave paintings.

Authors: Datta, PS
Book Editors: Lollino, G; Arattano, M; Giardino, M; Oliveira, R; Peppoloni, S
Author Full Names: Datta, Partha Sarathi
Article Title: Need to Harness Geodiversity to Combat Disaster from Natural Hazards
Source Title: ENGINEERING GEOLOGY FOR SOCIETY AND TERRITORY, VOL 7: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL ETHICS AND PUBLIC RECOGNITION OF ENGINEERING GEOLOGY
Author Keywords: Geoethics; Geo-diversity; Natural hazards; Disaster
Abstract: In most of high seismic zones parts of the world, limited knowledge on the heterogeneity in landform changes and geological formation causes threat from natural hazards disasters to the population. In absence of hazard resilient coherent long-term management policies, disasters result due to human failure to introduce proper preparedness measures, and tendency to manage vulnerability and risks by ad hoc and tactical approaches. To manage, prevent or mitigate hazards, efforts should be reoriented and consolidated to educate all stakeholders (including politicians, policy-makers and public) that they have to consider ` Geo-diversity' in their choices, and how they can overcome impacts by critical analysis of geo-ethical dilemmas, guided by the choices from the Geo-techniques based best obtainable detailed scientific information, and socio-economical considerations. Efforts by reliable, competent, capable and transparent institutions, to characterize the geo-regime spatiotemporal variability by integrated disciplinary approach, can help to harness the 'Geo-diversity' and ensure proper search and selection of the location of sites for planning the construction and maintenance of infrastructures. For better preparedness strategies, management plans and policies, discouraging corrupt and unscrupulous practices for private gain, can help to enhance efficiency and promote harmony by individuals trust, knowledge, transparency, respect of interests, share of responsibility and resources. This critical subject matter on how to harness the geo-diversity to combat hazard has been discussed here, through broader implications of an example of hazards and disasters in North India.
